In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia function `timezone_bumper`. 

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == DateTime
        return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
    elseif typeof(dt) == Date
        error("Date type is not allowed, please provide a DateTime")
    else
        error("Invalid input")
    end
end
```
This function first checks whether the input `dt` is of the `DateTime` type. If it is, it returns the date/time object after adding `bump` hours to it.

If `dt` is not a `DateTime`, but rather a `Date`, then an error message will be printed to console and function will end with an error. 

In case of invalid input type (not `DateTime` nor `Date`), the function again throws an error.
